0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-britain-idUSKCN0Y82RI	Trump changes tune on UK's Cameron: now sees 'a good relationship'	"
NEW YORK Donald Trump appeared to change tack on Tuesday about his future ties with British Prime Minister David Cameron
column2: saying he expects them to have ""a good relationship"" if he becomes the U.S. president
column3: after predicting the opposite in an interview aired just the day before in response to criticism from the UK leader.""He's got plenty of problems
column4: and I think he was inappropriate. So that's fine. ... I'm sure I'll have a good relationship with him
column5: Trump told Reuters in an interview.On Monday
column6: in an interview broadcast on Britain's ITV television station
column8: ""It looks like we're not going to have a very good relationship
column9: who knows?"" when asked how ties would fare if he won the U.S. presidential election on Nov. 8.

column1: Cameron criticized Trump in the British parliament over his call for a temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States
column2: calling him ""divisive
column3: stupid and wrong."" The prime minister suggested that the New York billionaire
column4: who is now the presumptive Republican presidential nominee
column5: would unite Britain against him if he visited.

column1: Asked which foreign leader he would like to meet first
column2: Trump told Reuters: ""I have no preference in terms of timing. I'll meet them
column3: we'll have a better relationship with foreign countries than we have right now. We don't have a good relationship. Every one of them rips us off but we still don't have a good relationship.""

column1: (Reporting by Steve Holland; Writing by Eric Walsh; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"
1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-banks-idUSKCN0Y900J	Trump preparing plan to dismantle Obama's Wall Street reform law	"
By Emily Flitter and Steve Holland
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump said on Tuesday that sweeping financial reforms put in place under President Barack Obama were harming the economy and he would dismantle nearly all of them.Trump told Reuters in an interview that he would release a plan in about two weeks for overhauling the 2010 financial regulatory law known as Dodd-Frank.""Dodd-Frank has made it impossible for bankers to function
column2: the presumptive Republican nominee said. ""It makes it very hard for bankers to loan money for people to create jobs
column3: for people with businesses to create jobs. And that has to stop.""Pressed on the extent of the changes he wanted to make
column5: ""it will be close to dismantling of Dodd-Frank.""Reacting on Twitter to Trump's comment
column6: Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton called it a ""reckless idea"" that would ""leave middle-class families out to dry.""Dodd-Frank
column7: passed in the aftermath of the 2007-2009 financial crisis
column8: forced U.S. banks to reduce their reliance on debt for funding and to craft ""living wills
column9: or blueprints for winding them down in a crisis.The law created a new agency
column11: to oversee consumer financial products such as mortgages and gave regulators new powers over large non-bank financial companies.

column1: INDUSTRY PRESSES FOR TWEAKS

Republicans in Congress have pushed to ease the requirements on small- and medium-sized banks and to make it more difficult for regulators to introduce new rules. They have also argued for getting rid of the consumer financial protection agency.Banks and other financial firms have spent six years and millions of dollars adjusting their operations to comply with the law. Bank lobbyists have generally pushed for changes to make complying easier
column2: rather than a wholesale rewrite.

column1: Every law can be improved
column2: and Dodd-Frank is no exception. Sometimes there are drafting errors. Sometimes a good idea in theory turns out to be unworkable after a closer look in the light of day
column3: said John Hall
column4: a spokesman for the American Bankers Association.Alison Hawkins
column5: a spokesman for the Financial Services Roundtable
column6: a Washington-based financial industry trade group
column7: said the group wanted to know more about Trump's plan
column8: and added ""some fixes to Dodd-Frank will benefit consumers and the economy.""On Capitol Hill
column10: the chairman of the House Financial Services Committee
column11: plans to release his own financial regulation plan in the coming weeks
column15: Rozier said. She added that Hensarling
column17: has not discussed his plan with any of the presidential candidates.

column1: But Dennis Kelleher of Better Markets
column2: a group that favors tighter regulation of Wall Street
column3: said Trump's plan would be ""a slap in the face to the American people who have suffered so much from the 2008 crash.""Trump declined to offer specifics on his plan
column4: but said it would address whether institutions should separate commercial banking activities from investment banking. He said even under the new plan
column5: the banking system would not be perfect. ""Will there be bad loans made? Yes. But there are bad loans made now with Dodd-Frank
column6: Trump said.Trump was reluctant to discuss specifics on his ideas for the economy before his upcoming speech
column7: but he praised Federal Reserve Chairman Janet Yellen
column8: saying he approved of her decision to keep interest rates low. Trump has said in the past he would replace Yellen once her term as Fed chair ended.""I'm not a person that thinks Janet Yellen is doing a bad job
column9: he told Reuters. ""I would rather have a Republican in the position but I am not the enemy of Janet Yellen."" (Reporting By Emily Flitter and Steve Holland in New York; Additional reporting by Lauren LaCapra and Ross Kerber in New York
column10: Emily Stephenson and Alana Wise in Washington: Editing by Caren Bohan and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-hillary-finances-idUSKCN0Y904G	Clinton releases personal financial disclosure
column2: calls on Trump to release income taxes	"

column1: WASHINGTON Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton on Tuesday released her personal financial disclosure form
column2: covering Jan. 1
column5: with a call to Republican Donald Trump to make available his income tax returns.   ""The true test for Donald Trump is whether he will adhere to the precedent followed by every presidential candidate in the modern era and make his tax returns available
column7: spokeswoman Christina Reynolds said in a statement. Clinton's own disclosure form showed more than $5 million in royalties from her memoir ""Hard Choices.""

column1: Trump earlier in the day announced that he had filed his personal financial disclosure to the Federal Election Commission on Monday.
(Reporting by Alana Wise; Editing by Leslie Adler)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-army-fanning-idUSKCN0Y82LM	Senate backs Fanning as Army secretary	"
WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate unanimously backed President Barack Obama's nomination of Eric Fanning as secretary of the Army on Tuesday
column2: making him the first openly gay leader of a U.S. military service branch.Fanning was previously undersecretary of the Air Force and chief of staff to Defense Secretary Ash Carter.Fanning was confirmed by unanimous voice vote
column3: eight months following his nomination
column4: after Senator Pat Roberts said Deputy Defense Secretary Robert Work told him that it was now too late for the administration to transfer prisoners from the detention center at Guantanamo Bay
column7: Kansas.Work did not confirm Roberts' account of that conversation
column8: saying that no option was off the table.""I explained to Senator Roberts that we are trying to achieve the goal of closure with the support of Congress and we recognize that there is limited time left to achieve that support
column9: both in terms of lifting Congressional restrictions and winning approval of funds to execute closure
column10: Work said in a statement. Roberts had held up Fanning's nomination for months to  underscore his opposition to any possible transfer of detainees.

column1: His opposition had frustrated fellow Republican John McCain
column2: chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and a strong supporter of Fanning's nomination.On Tuesday
column3: McCain and Roberts appeared in the Senate together as Roberts announced that he had released his ""hold"" on Fanning and spoken to Fanning.McCain noted that this year's National Defense Authorization Act ensures that the Obama administration does not have the authority to release or transfer Guantanamo detainees to the U.S. mainland.

column1: Roberts said Work told him during a meeting last week that he would be unable to fulfill an order to move Guantanamo detainees to the United States before Obama leaves office in January 2017.""The clock has run out for the president
column2: Roberts said.

column1: (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Jonathan Oatis
column2: Bernard Orr and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-reaction-idUSKCN0Y82RO	Clinton aide criticizes Trump has having 'bizarre fascination with foreign strongmen'	"

WASHINGTON An aide to U.S. Democrat Hillary Clinton criticized Donald Trump's foreign policy as making ""no sense for the rest of us"" after the Republican presidential candidate said he would hold talks with North Korea's Kim Jong Un. ""Let me get this straight: Donald Trump insults the leader of our closest ally
column2: then turns around and says he'd love to talk to Kim Jong Un?"" senior foreign policy adviser Jake Sullivan said in a statement. ""I suppose that makes sense for him
column3: since he also praised Kim Jong Un for executing his uncle and seems to have a bizarre fascination with foreign strongmen like Putin and Kim. His approach to foreign policy makes no sense for the rest of us.""

column1: (Reporting by Ginger Gibson; Editing by Leslie Adler)"

WASHINGTON Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton on Tuesday criticized Republican Donald Trump's proposal to dismantle the Dodd-Frank financial reform law

column3: and leave middle-class families out to dry

6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trumpuniversity-idUSKCN0Y8294	Judges rule Trump University can appeal to New York's highest court	"
By Karen Freifeld
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK A New York appeals court issued a ruling on Tuesday that apparently made it highly unlikely that a state fraud case against Trump University
column2: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's venture
column3: will be heard before the Nov. 8 general election.The mid-level appeals court ruled that Trump's lawyers can argue to the state's highest court that the fraud claims against Trump University brought by the state attorney general should be dismissed. Trump suffered a legal setback in the case in March when the appeals court allowed multimillion-dollar fraud claims against the now-defunct venture to proceed. The claims are part of a state lawsuit filed in 2013 that accuses Trump University of misleading thousands of people who paid up to $35
column4: 000 for seminars to learn the billionaire businessman's real estate investment strategies.The trial judge in the case had been waiting to hear whether the mid-level appeals court
column8: would give Trump permission to go to the state's highest court

column1: It's no surprise that Donald Trump is using every legal option to avoid standing trial for operating a sham for-profit university
column2: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman said in a statement responding to the ruling. ""As our lawsuit makes clear
column3: Mr. Trump's phony university defrauded thousands of students through an illicit scheme that cost them millions of dollars
column4: Schneiderman continued. ""I am confident that the Court of Appeals will agree with the lower court's unanimous decision to reject virtually all of Mr. Trump's claims.""Alan Garten
column5: general counsel for the Trump Organization
column7: ""We are pleased with the court's decision and look forward to going to the Court of Appeals.""

column1: Garten has said the claims are ""without merit and baseless"" and that almost all those who participated in the programs filled out written surveys giving the seminars high ratings.Class actions are pending in California on similar claims by Trump University students. One of those cases is scheduled for trial on Nov. 28.The fraud claims against Trump University were an issue early in the Republican primary campaign.
With Trump allowed to appeal the pretrial rulings to the state's highest court
column2: it is very unlikely the New York case will be resolved before November's election.It takes an average of 12 months from the time an appeal is allowed for the Court of Appeals to hear oral arguments in a case
column3: according to court spokesman Gary Spencer. A decision on whether or not the fraud claims can proceed would normally take another month and
column5: the case would then go back to the trial court. In the March decision
column6: Schneiderman was allowed to proceed on fraud claims that require proof of intent to defraud and those that do not. The court also ruled that the statute of limitations for the claims stretches back to 2007 instead of 2010. The program stopped taking students in 2010. (Reporting by Karen Freifeld; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-taxes-idUSKCN0Y82KO	Donald Trump files disclosure of $10 billion in net worth	"
By Ginger Gibson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Donald Trump has filed a new personal financial disclosure form that details a net worth of more than $10 billion
column2: the Republican presidential candidate's campaign said on Tuesday.The party's presumptive nominee has refused so far to release his income tax statements
column3: which are normally released by presidential candidates. That decision has drawn criticism from likely Democratic rival Hillary Clinton.

column1: The personal disclosure form is identical to one Trump filed shortly after announcing his candidacy last year. Critics have said the billionaire real estate developer is inflating his net worth in the forms and that his tax documents would provide a more accurate depiction of how much money he has.
I have built an incredible company and have accumulated one of the greatest portfolios of real estate assets
column2: many of which are considered to be among the finest and most iconic properties in the world
column3: Trump said in a statement about his disclosure.

column1: (Reporting by Ginger Gibson; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"
8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-defense-women-idUSKCN0Y82J2	House drops military draft requirement for women	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The House of Representatives stripped a requirement that women register for the military draft from a sweeping annual defense policy bill on Tuesday
column2: but supporters of the provision said they would keep pushing for its passage.Democrats accused the committee's Republican leaders of using an underhanded ploy to undercut the House Armed Services Committee
column3: which had approved the amendment
column4: and avoid what could be a difficult vote for some party members.""They don't want to subject their members to a vote on equality for women
column8: chairman of the House Armed Services Committee
column9: said the amendment was removed because it violated House budget rules due to the cost of  registering women. He said it was replaced with an amendment calling for a broad review of the Selective Service.The House Rules Committee set up removal of the amendment from the National Defense Authorization Act
column11: during a meeting late on Monday. It was taken out of the bill via a procedural vote on Tuesday afternoon.

column1: But the effort is not dead. The Senate Armed Services Committee included a similar amendment in its version of the NDAA
column2: and it has bipartisan support in the Senate.The Senate's Republican Majority Leader
column3: Mitch McConnell
column4: said he believed women should register
column5: although he did not expect the country to reinstate the draft.

column1: Given where we are today with women in the military performing virtually all kinds of functions
column2: I personally think it would be appropriate for them to register just like men do
column3: McConnell told a news conference.Defense Secretary Ash Carter announced last year that all combat positions would be open to women
column4: which immediately prompted calls that women also should be required to register. That worried some social conservatives uncomfortable with the blurring of men's and women's traditional roles in society.The U.S. military has been an all-volunteer force since the 1970s
column5: but young men have been required to sign up for the Selective Service in case the draft is reactivated.

column1: To become law as part of the NDAA
column2: a version of the defense bill with the amendment would have to be approved by the full House and Senate
column3: and signed by President Barack Obama. (Additional reporting by Richard Cowan; Editing by Dan Grebler)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-philippines-politics-usa-obama-idUSKCN0Y82BZ	Obama speaks to Philippines' president-elect
column2: stresses human rights	"

column1: WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama called incoming Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte on Tuesday to congratulate him on his election win
column2: stressing that their countries' alliance was based on a commitment to human rights and the rule of law
column3: the White House said.U.S. officials have signaled that Washington is ready to work with Duterte despite allegations of human rights abuses in the city he led as mayor for over two decades.Obama's deputy national security adviser
column5: told a Washington seminar earlier on Tuesday that the U.S. administration was aware there was some ""controversy"" surrounding Duterte and ""statements that drew attention in the past
column6: but he did not elaborate.Obama offered his congratulations to Duterte as the ""presumptive president-elect.""He won the largest share of the votes in a May 9 presidential election
column7: according to an unofficial count by a poll watchdog
column8: although the official result has yet to be confirmed.Obama ""highlighted the enduring values that underpin our thriving alliance ... and the longstanding ties between our two peoples
column9: including our shared commitments to democracy

column1: Washington hoped ""to build on progress made with the last administration"" in the Philippines
column2: Rhodes said.""This is a new government and we'll want to hear from them directly what their priorities are
column3: he said when asked about the election
column4: adding that Washington wanted to see continued efforts to respect the rule of law and combat corruption.Duterte has been criticized for allowing a spree of vigilante killings under his administration in Davao city
column5: and critics fear he could let them happen on a larger scale as president.

column1: He has denied ordering any of the killings
column2: but has not condemned them.Washington has steered clear of the controversy
column3: however
column4: which analysts say reflects the reality of U.S. national security interests given China's increasingly assertive stance in Asia and maritime disputes in the South China Sea.Duterte's vows to restore law and order resonated with voters
column5: but his incendiary rhetoric and advocacy of extrajudicial killings to stamp out crime and drugs have alarmed many people.

column1: Rhodes noted U.S. support for Manila efforts to resolve its territorial dispute with China in the South China Sea through international arbitration
column2: and a recent deal allowing a greater U.S. military presence in the Philippines. ""We believe that now as much as ever it's important that the U.S. and Philippines are seen working together
column3: he said.The U.S. stance on Duterte could echo its approach toward India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi. At one point
column4: Modi was unable to obtain a U.S. visa because of concerns about sectarian riots in the state of Gujarat when he was chief minister
column5: but was later invited to the White House when he became prime minister. (Reporting by Matt Spetalnick and David Brunnstrom; editing by Tom Brown and G Crosse)"
